You’re on Ops. Debugging  Error-s in Invoicing Rails app, as usual. They’re stored in MySQL and accessed through ActiveRecord and some helper methods. They’ve already been updated with a  status_message, so now it’s time to dig in and investigate.
  The sun beams through your window on another record-high heat wave afternoon, but you’re cool as a cucumber: you brought your sunglasses and a tall glass of trusty H2O.
         Another 23.7 seconds pass and you decide to  CTRL-C your way out of there before you cause a production incident. You decide to just pull the  Error IDs from the JIRA ticket like a pleb. Suddenly the heat wave feels even hotter.
  But this is nagging you. I mean, what gives?? Why doesn’t this method ever just do the thing it says on the tin? Sure, if we use the  .no_status scope ( WHERE status_message IS NOT NULL) it seems to work, but why can’t we get simple text search to work on this column? Sure there are a lot (a lot =  8612441) rows, but I feel like I’ve seen text searching work before. Should we switch to  Postgres?
  Sargable is a gate keep-y portmanteau (<- also gate keep-y. A portmanteau is a word that smashes together the sounds and meaning of two words, like spoon + fork = spork) for “search argument-able”. We use the term to describe the ability of the database’s SQL optimizer to leverage an index. There are a few things that determine a query’s sargability (not sure if that’s a word), but a big one to look out for is using wildcards ( %) when doing text searches.
 Let’s look at the implementation of our  where_message_like method to see if we might be running into something like this.
 irb ( main ): 001 : 0 >  ActiveRecord :: Base . connection . to_sql ( Error . where_message_like ( "NoMethodError: undefined method `is_approved_by_finance? \\ ' for nil:NilClass" )) =>  "SELECT `errors`.* FROM `errors` WHERE (message like '%NoMethodError: undefined method `is_approved_by_finance? \'  for nil:NilClass%')"
 Aha, so we have a wildcard ( %) on either end of string in the  WHERE clause:
  To understand why this is a problem, let’s pretend your the SQL query optimizer. Let’s say that I ask you to find all of the words in the dictionary that contain the substring  get:
  You’ll have to scan through  every word (row) in the dictionary ( entries table) to find all of the instances:
  If, instead, I asked you to get all of the words in the dictionary that  begin with  get, you could just flip to the correct page and give me all the words! In this way, the dictionary being in alphabetical order is a type of index:
   “But, Thomas”, I hear you asking, “what if we want to do a substring search rather than search from the beginning of the string?”
 That’s a great question! For our  Error scenario, that’s seldom the case, but there are more intentional indexes we  could use to get us a more robust sub-string search, like  MySQL’s  FULLTEXT or  Postgres’  ts_vector. It’s worth noting that full-text indexes aren’t magic and your tables and queries have to change to support them.
 For our example, we don’t have these things readily at our disposal, so we’ll continue with the assumption that we’re searching for a substring at the  beginning of the column’s contents.
  So now, let’s see this sargable business in action by looking at the query plans!
  irb ( main ): 002 : 0 >  puts  ActiveRecord :: Base . connection . explain ( Error . where_message_like ( "NoMethodError: undefined method `is_approved_by_finance? \\ ' for nil:NilClass" ). to_sql )  EXPLAIN  ( 0.5 ms )  EXPLAIN  SELECT  `errors` . *  FROM  `errors`  WHERE  ( message  like  '%NoMethodError: undefined method `is_approved_by_finance?\' for nil:NilClass%' ) +----+-------------+----------------+------+---------------+------+---------+------+---------+-------------+ |  id  |  select_type  |  table  |  type  |  possible_keys  |  key  |  key_len  |  ref  |  rows  |  Extra  | +----+-------------+----------------+------+---------------+------+---------+------+---------+-------------+ |  1  |  SIMPLE  |  errors  |  ALL  |  NULL  |  NULL  |  NULL  |  NULL  |  6739497  |  Using  where  | +----+-------------+----------------+------+---------------+------+---------+------+---------+-------------+ 1  row  in  set  ( 0.00  sec )
  irb ( main ): 003 : 0 >  puts  ActiveRecord :: Base . connection . explain ( Error . where ( "message LIKE  \' NoMethodError: undefined method `is_approved_by_finance? \\ ' for nil:NilClass% \' " ). to_sql )  EXPLAIN  ( 0.5 ms )  EXPLAIN  SELECT  `errors` . *  FROM  `errors`  WHERE  ( message  LIKE  'NoMethodError: undefined method `is_approved_by_finance?\' for nil:NilClass%' ) +----+-------------+----------------+------+---------------+------+---------+------+---------+-------------+ |  id  |  select_type  |  table  |  type  |  possible_keys  |  key  |  key_len  |  ref  |  rows  |  Extra  | +----+-------------+----------------+------+---------------+------+---------+------+---------+-------------+ |  1  |  SIMPLE  |  errors  |  ALL  |  NULL  |  NULL  |  NULL  |  NULL  |  6739497  |  Using  where  | +----+-------------+----------------+------+---------------+------+---------+------+---------+-------------+ 1  row  in  set  ( 0.00  sec )
 Oh crap. What’ gives?! They look exactly the same! Why isn’t MySQL optimizing! We sarged(?) it!
 Unfortunately for us, our  message doesn’t have an index. Further, the column is a  TEXT column, and (given it’s extremely varied and undefined length) if we want to add an index, MySQL  requires us to specify a  prefix length, which tells MySQL how much of the  beginning of the string should be indexed. Further further, only the InnoDB tables can be index this way. (Our  errors table uses the InnoDB engine, so no problem there).
  Even though our  message  TEXT column doesn’t have an index, our  ticket_id column does:
 irb ( main ): 004 : 0 >  puts  ActiveRecord :: Base . connection . explain ( 'errors' )  EXPLAIN  ( 2.6 ms )  EXPLAIN  errors +---------------------+--------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+ |  Field  |  Type  |  Null  |  Key  |  Default  |  Extra  | +---------------------+--------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+ |  id  |  int ( 11 )  |  NO  |  PRI  |  NULL  |  auto_increment  | |  message  |  text  |  YES  |  |  NULL  |  | |  backtrace  |  text  |  YES  |  |  NULL  |  | |  status_message  |  varchar ( 255 )  |  YES  |  MUL  |  NULL  |  | |  created_at  |  datetime  |  YES  |  |  NULL  |  | |  updated_at  |  datetime  |  YES  |  |  NULL  |  | |  runtime_environment  |  text  |  YES  |  |  NULL  |  | |  error_type  |  varchar ( 255 )  |  YES  |  MUL  |  NULL  |  | |  ticket_id  |  varchar ( 255 )  |  YES  |  MUL  |  NULL  |  | +---------------------+--------------+------+-----+---------+----------------+ 9  rows  in  set  ( 0.00  sec )
 The  ticket_id column is of type  varchar(255), which means we have no problem putting an index on there. And that’s exactly what we did! In our case, it uses a  MUL, or “Multiple”, key meaning that it’s value is used at the beginning of a non-unique key (multiple records can have the same index).
 Let’s look at how our knowledge of sargable wildcard queries plays a role with this type of column.
  irb ( main ): 005 : 0 >  puts  ActiveRecord :: Base . connection . explain ( Error . where ( 'ticket_id LIKE \'%A00057440\'' ). to_sql )  EXPLAIN  ( 0.5 ms )  EXPLAIN  SELECT  `errors` . *  FROM  `errors`  WHERE  ( ticket_id  LIKE  '%A00057440%' ) +----+-------------+----------------+------+---------------+------+---------+------+---------+-------------+ |  id  |  select_type  |  table  |  type  |  possible_keys  |  key  |  key_len  |  ref  |  rows  |  Extra  | +----+-------------+----------------+------+---------------+------+---------+------+---------+-------------+ |  1  |  SIMPLE  |  errors  |  ALL  |  NULL  |  NULL  |  NULL  |  NULL  |  8612441  |  Using  where  | +----+-------------+----------------+------+---------------+------+---------+------+---------+-------------+ 1  row  in  set  ( 0.00  sec )
  irb ( main ): 006 : 0 >  puts  ActiveRecord :: Base . connection . explain ( Error . where ( 'ticket_id LIKE \'%A00057440\'' ). to_sql )  EXPLAIN  ( 1.2 ms )  EXPLAIN  SELECT  `errors` . *  FROM  `errors`  WHERE  ( ticket_id  LIKE  'A00057440%' ) +----+-------------+----------------+-------+--------------------------------------+--------------------------------------+---------+------+------+-----------------------+ |  id  |  select_type  |  table  |  type  |  possible_keys  |  key  |  key_len  |  ref  |  rows  |  Extra  | +----+-------------+----------------+-------+--------------------------------------+--------------------------------------+---------+------+------+-----------------------+ |  1  |  SIMPLE  |  errors  |  range  |  index_errors_on_ticket_id  |  index_errors_on_ticket_id  |  768  |  NULL  |  214  |  Using  index  condition  | +----+-------------+----------------+-------+--------------------------------------+--------------------------------------+---------+------+------+-----------------------+ 1  row  in  set  ( 0.00  sec )
 Aha! In the first query plan, MySQL tells us it will scan through  ALL  8612441 rows  Using where. The second, sargable, query plan tells us that it will only need to scan through a  range of  214 by  Using index condition!
  I’ll leave it as an exercise for the reader to  SET profiling = 1; to see the real cost. See: https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/show-profile.html
  Ahhh, the sun is finally starting to set. We haven’t finished (or really even begun) our investigation, but we’re a little wiser about MySQL’s indexing patterns.
 How can we use this knowledge to make our jobs a little easier and beat the heat?
 I guess the first thing to know is that  where_message_like could take a very long time if there are no other  WHERE conditions. This is because it’s a  TEXT column with no index, but even if it had an index, using a wildcard at the front of our search string isn’t doing us any favors.
 Also, it’s nice to know that the  ticket_id column  is indexed, and if we want to search, we can use a sargable query to get our results much faster! Having a consistent format for  ticket_id might be something to consider; if we can deduce what the beginning of the string is, finding all of the relevant records could be super efficient!
 Lastly, if we did want to index the  message column, we have a few options:
 We could migrate it from  TEXT to  VARCHAR. The advantage there is gaining access to an easy index, but we give up the  benefits of choosing  TEXT in the first place.
 We could use a  column prefix key by specifying a prefix limit. That might get us some good bang for our buck if we use sargable queries.
 Or, we could invest in a  full-text index and really leverage what InnoDB can do! However, this will require us to alter our table a bit more and adjust our query patterns. Whether or not this plays nice with Rails is another question we’d need to answer.
 Nevertheless, it’s 5:00pm (4:56PM, but who’s counting), so it’s time to call it a day and grab the last few rays of sun down by the water.
 Before you  ⌘-Q out of Slack, you remember something. “…didn’t Brianna say that they were going to look at this issue??”

Romero) 1985 年经典僵尸恐怖电影《亡灵节》(Day of the Dead) 重新启动电视的消息——就在一场致命的全球大流行开始之前，同样如此。不知何故，尽管所有的停工，该系列还是设法投入生产。 SyFy 在 Comic-Con@home 的一个小组讨论中放弃了十集系列的官方预告片，计划于今年 10 月首映，正好赶上万圣节。您可以在此处观看完整的 45 分钟面板。最初的《亡灵之日》是推出系列电影的三部曲中的第三部，之前是《亡灵之夜》（1968）及其续集《亡者黎明》（1978）。罗梅罗最初将《亡灵节》设想为僵尸电影的“飘”，但与制片厂在提议的 R 评级上存在分歧——罗梅罗希望这部电影不被评级——意味着导演最终只有他最初预算的一半（大约400 万美元）。他被迫大幅缩小自己的视野，因此影片的大部分内容都发生在大沼泽地的一个安全地下掩体中，现场的科学家和士兵之间的紧张局势加剧。罗梅罗表示《亡灵节》是他在系列中最喜欢的，尽管它在最初三部曲的烂番茄上的“新鲜”评分最低（83%）。它在全球的票房收入仅为 3400 万美元（主要来自 VHS、DVD 和蓝光发行），但它仍然在流行文化中留下了印记。伪文明丧尸“Bub”客串了《行尸走肉》S4集，作为在铁路隧道中遇到的“行尸走肉”之一。而在《怪奇物语 S3》（设定于 1985 年）中，青少年们都潜入商场剧院观看亡灵节的早期放映。该系列中的另外三部电影于 2005 年、2007 年和 2009 年上映，而《活死人之夜 II》目前正在制作中，定于 2022 年上映。死亡之日的三位原始演员将在这部电影中重新扮演他们的角色。早在 SyFy 项目宣布时，《亡灵之日》电视剧的官方日志将其描述为“六个陌生人试图在不死入侵的前 24 小时内幸存下来的激烈故事”。它一直是对罗梅罗的颂歌，他几乎是整个流派的先驱。 “活死人之夜是在 1968 年，我们仍然，每次僵尸出现时，我们都会谈论罗梅罗，”联合节目主持人（与 Jed Elinoff）斯科特·托马斯在小组讨论中说道。 “他建立了我们所知的现代僵尸……而且他以一种也增加了社会评论的方式做到了这一点。每部僵尸电影、电视节目或图画小说都欠罗梅罗的遗产。”从预告片来看，我们将得到我们那份以僵尸为燃料的血腥：四肢被扯断、内脏，当然还有美味的大脑的消耗。根据托马斯的说法，在整个系列赛中还将为鹰眼球迷散布复活节彩蛋。就我个人而言，我希望再次见到巴布（带着他嘲弄的敬礼），甚至可能是化妆/特效大师汤姆·萨维尼，他​​是原版三部曲的成员。 （萨维尼在去年的 NOS4A2 和 Locke and Key 中作为演员出人意料地客串演出。）也就是说，该系列也将与那些经典的罗梅罗电影大相径庭。例如，看起来有更多的幽默感。虽然该节目将以经典的罗梅罗“慢”僵尸为特色，但托马斯表示，僵尸入侵不会是爆发将每个人都变成僵尸的结果。相反，这将是一个场景，死者开始复活并吃掉故事发生的小镇的居民。 （在这方面，它类似于 2019 年的《死者不死》的前提。）据托马斯说，僵尸不能通过简单的头部射击轻易杀死，这应该会更加危险。亡灵节将于 2021 年 10 月在 SyFy 首映。 演员包括娜塔莉·马拉卡饰演劳伦·豪威尔，基南·特蕾西饰演卡姆·麦克德莫特，丹尼尔·多赫尼饰演卢克·鲍曼，摩根·霍姆斯特罗姆饰演莎拉·布莱克伍德，米兰达·弗里贡饰演宝拉·鲍曼，迪扬·洛约拉饰演杰·费舍尔， Kristy Dawn Dinsmore 饰演 Amy，Christopher Russell 饰演 Trey Bowman，Matty Finochio 饰演 Bobby Hart，Kevin O'Grady 饰演 Rhodes，Lucia Walters 饰演 Logan，Stefanie von Pfetten 饰演 Cindy，Darryl Scheelar 饰演 Magnum，Trezzo Mahoro 饰演 Trent，Caitlin Stryker 饰演 Nicole和 Marci T. House 饰演派克船长。人们假设其中一些演员最终会成为僵尸食物。
note_en:
Somehow I missed the news last February that SyFy  had greenlit a TV reboot of George A. Romero's classic 1985 zombie horror film,  Day of the Dead—just before the widespread onset of a deadly global pandemic, no less. And somehow the series managed to get into production despite all the shutdowns. SyFy dropped the official trailer for the ten-episode series during a panel at Comic-Con@home, with a planned premiere date this October, just in time for Halloween. You can watch the full 45-minute panel  here.
 The original   Day of the Dead was the third in a trilogy of films that launched a franchise, preceded by   Night of the Living the Dead (1968) and its sequel,   Dawn of the Dead (1978). Romero originally envisioned  Day of the Dead as the  Gone With the Wind of zombie movies, but disagreements with the studio over a proposed R-rating—Romero wanted the film to be unrated—meant that the director ended up with half his original budget (about $4 million). He was forced to scale back his vision substantially, so much of the film takes place in a secure underground bunker in the Everglades, where tensions rise between the scientists and soldiers on-site.
 Romero has said that  Day of the Dead is his favorite within the franchise, although it has the lowest "fresh" rating (83 percent) on Rotten Tomatoes of the initial trilogy. It only grossed $34 million worldwide (mostly from VHS, DVD, and Blu-Ray releases), but it still left its mark on popular culture. The pseudo-civilized zombie "Bub" made a cameo on a S4 episode of  The Walking Dead as one of the "walkers" encountered in a railroad tunnel. And in   Stranger Things S3 (set in 1985), the teens all sneak into a mall theater to watch an early screening of  Day of the Dead. Three more films in the franchise were released in 2005, 2007, and 2009, and  Night of the Living Dead II is currently in production, slated for a 2022 release. Three of the original cast members from  Day of the Dead will reprise their roles in that film.
 Back when the SyFy project  was announced, the official logline for the  Day of the Dead TV series described it as "the intense story of six strangers trying to survive the first 24 hours of an undead invasion." It was always intended as an ode to Romero, who pretty much pioneered the entire genre.  “Night of the Living Dead was in 1968, and we’re still, every time zombies come up, we talk about Romero,” co-showrunner (with Jed Elinoff) Scott Thomas said during the panel. “He established what we know as the modern zombie... and he did it in a way that also added social commentary. Every single zombie movie or TV show or graphic novel owes Romero for his legacy.”
    Judging from the trailer, we'll get our share of zombie-fueled gore: limbs torn off, disembowelment, and of course, the consumption of tasty brains. There will also be Easter eggs scattered throughout the series for eagle-eyed fans, per Thomas. Personally, I'm hoping to see Bub again (with his mocking salute), and maybe even makeup/special effects master  Tom Savini, a crew member on the original trilogy. (Savini made surprise cameo appearances as an actor in last year's   NOS4A2 and   Locke and Key.)
 That said, the series will also depart significantly from those classic Romero movies. For instance, it looks like there be a lot more humor. And while the show will feature the classic Romero "slow" zombies, Thomas said that the zombie invasion will not be the result of an outbreak that starts turning everyone into zombies. Rather, it will be a scenario where the dead start coming back to life and eating the residents of the small town in which the story takes place. (In that respect, it resembles the premise of 2019's  T he Dead Don't Die.) And the zombies cannot be killed as easily by a simple shot to the head, according to Thomas, which should up the stakes even more.
 Day of the Dead premieres on SyFy in October 2021. The cast includes Natalie Malaika as Lauren Howell, Keenan Tracey as Cam McDermott, Daniel Doheny as Luke Bowman, Morgan Holmstrom as Sarah Blackwood, Miranda Frigon as Paula Bowman, Deejan Loyola as Jai Fisher, Kristy Dawn Dinsmore as Amy, Christopher Russell as Trey Bowman, Matty Finochio as Bobby Hart, Kevin O'Grady as Rhodes, Lucia Walters as Logan, Stefanie von Pfetten as Cindy, Darryl Scheelar as Magnum, Trezzo Mahoro as Trent, Caitlin Stryker as Nicole, and Marci T. House as Captain Pike. One assumes a few of those cast members will end up as zombie food.

自周三发射以来，俄罗斯空间站模块 Nauka 经历了一系列恐慌。截至周五下午，俄罗斯新发射的国际空间站模块 Nauka 仍在战斗中，因为早期报道表明该模块的备用引擎已成功点火。这对 Roscosmos 来说是一个很大的解脱，它几乎看到其期待已久的模块变成了一个悲惨的太空琐事，而不是国际空间站的最新部分。但它还没有走出困境。 Nauka 旅程的第一个故障发生在昨天，当时航天器没有完成它的第一次轨道提升燃烧。这意味着未载人的 Nauka 无法实际拦截国际空间站，它计划于 7 月 29 日星期四与之对接。 该问题归因于 Nauka 上一台计算机的软件问题，该问题阻止了航天器的主引擎射击。 Nauka 的团队能够管理远程路线修正，但第二轮路线修正被认为是必要的，并安排在今天。记者阿纳托利·扎克 (Anatoly Zak) 的一份早期报告表明，航天器的一个引擎在执行任务时突然恢复了生命。哈佛-史密森天体物理中心的天体物理学家乔纳森·麦克道威尔 (Jonathan McDowell) 在今天的一封电子邮件中说，“备用引擎似乎点火正常”，但他补充说，引擎的状态尚不确定，很可能是几个小时前，来自 Nauka 的新数据集验证了这种情况。推进器只是工程难题的一部分，因此新模块几乎是免费的。据 SpaceNews 报道，Nauka 也遇到了一根天线及其对接目标的问题，并且不确定这些问题将如何影响对接尝试。麦克道尔说：“显然，库尔斯会合系统仍然存在问题，这对对接非常关键，”并补充说，航天器的 TORU 系统——允许国际空间站上的宇航员协助对接——工作正常。目前，Pirs 对接舱目前位于国际空间站上 Nauka 指定的码头中。据俄罗斯太空网报道，皮尔斯原定的为新模块让路的计划从周五推迟到周日。 “复杂的航天器出现初期问题并不罕见。然而，这次飞行中问题的数量和严重程度超出了常态，考虑到车辆开发的长期延误，这也许并不令人意外。尽管如此，我对他们最终将完成成功对接持适度乐观态度，尽管不一定是第一次尝试，”麦克道尔说。留意这艘宇宙飞船。这个故事肯定还有一两个转折。
我对他们最终会成功对接持适度乐观的态度，尽管不一定是第一次尝试听起来像我在 KSP 中！尽管如此，他们无法选择按 alt+F12 并获得无限推进剂。
note_en:
The Russian space station module Nauka has had a streak of panicky moments since its launch on Wednesday.
 Russia’s newly launched International Space Station module Nauka is still in the fight as of Friday afternoon, as early reports indicate that the module’s backup engines have fired successfully. That’s a big relief for Roscosmos, which nearly saw its long-awaited module become a tragic piece of space trivia instead of the newest piece of the International Space Station. But it’s not out of the woods yet.
  The first glitch in Nauka’s journey happened yesterday, when the spacecraft   didn’t complete its first orbit-raising burn. This meant that the uncrewed Nauka wasn’t on track to actually intercept the ISS, which it’s scheduled to dock with on Thursday, July 29. The problem was attributed to a software issue in a computer aboard Nauka, which prevented the spacecraft’s main engines from firing. Nauka’s team was able to manage a remote course correction, but a second bout of course corrections were deemed necessary, and scheduled for today.   One early report from journalist Anatoly Zak indicated that one of the spacecraft’s engines sputtered back to life in a mission. The “backup engine seems to have fired fine,” said Jonathan McDowell, an astrophysicist at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, in an email today, though he added that the status of the engines was not yet certain and it would likely be a few hours before a new dataset from Nauka verified the situation.
     The thrusters are just one piece of the engineering puzzle, so the new module is hardly home free. Nauka’s also been having issues with one antenna and its docking target, and its uncertain how those issues will affect docking attempts,   SpaceNews reported. “Apparently there is still an issue with the Kurs rendezvous system, and that is pretty critical for docking,” McDowell said, adding that the spacecraft’s TORU system—which allows the astronauts aboard the ISS assist with the docking—is working normally.
  For now, the Pirs docking compartment is currently sitting in Nauka’s assigned dock on the ISS. Pirs’ scheduled undocking to make way for the new module was postponed from Friday to Sunday,   according to RussianSpaceWeb.
   “It is not unusual for complex spacecraft to have teething troubles. However, the number and severity of problems on this flight is above the norm, and perhaps this is not too surprising given the long delays in the development of the vehicle. Nevertheless, I am moderately optimistic that they will eventually complete a successful docking, although not necessarily on the first attempt,” McDowell said.
 Keep your eyes on this spacecraft. There’s certainly a twist or two left in this tale.

上个月，一位在东非国家只待了几个月的法国初创公司创始人似乎毫不费力地为他的新食品配送应用筹集了 100 万美元的种子前资金，这在肯尼亚社交媒体上引起了轩然大波。与此同时，当地和地区的创始人表示，经过多年的尝试，他们仍然难以整合资金。上周与肯尼亚科技创始人谈论这件事时，我想起了 Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o 回忆录《战时梦想》中的一句话：“相信自己比无休止地担心别人对你的看法更重要。 ” Ngũgĩ 回忆起他在殖民时代肯尼亚的童年时代的一个实现时刻，但今天这句话感觉很贴切。在 2010 年代初期，肯尼亚刚刚起步的科技生态系统被用作更广泛的“非洲崛起”叙事的简写。随着初创公司的萌芽和技术人才涌向内罗毕，它很快被称为“硅谷大草原”。但到了 2016 年，当地圈子里纷纷议论说，这笔资金似乎不成比例地偏向于在该国创办公司的北美和欧洲创始人。事情在 2017 年达到顶峰，一份名为“打破常规”的乡村资本报告似乎证实了许多当地创始人和记者的说法：在东非，2015 年和 2016 年披露的创业投资中有 90% 流向了拥有一名或多名欧洲或北美创始人。 Village Capital 非洲和中东区域总监 Aedana Ashebir 告诉我，这是一个在过去五年中一直没有消失的问题。对 2019 年数据的分析显示，当年筹集超过 100 万美元的肯尼亚初创公司中，只有一家拥有本地创始人。四家初创公司的创始人是外国和本地创始人，而 11 家则是外籍创始人。值得注意的是，这种趋势并不适用于非洲大陆的其他地方：在拉各斯蓬勃发展的科技中心，同一分析中确定的创始人中有 55% (12) 是尼日利亚人，而在南非，56% (14) 的创始人是尼日利亚人。创始人是当地人。这种与其他非洲市场的比较只会加深肯尼亚许多长期技术观察者的挫败感。因此，上个月，当一位持有访客签证的年轻法国创始人 Robin Reecht 为肯尼亚食品配送应用程序 Kune 筹集了 100 万美元的种子前资金时，大家都皱起了眉头。但真正引发了#KOT（推特上的肯尼亚人）和肯尼亚社交媒体用户的强烈反对是随后对 TechCrunch 的采访。其中引用 Reecht 的话说，在肯尼亚仅仅三天后，他就注意到“不可能”以“便宜的价格”获得美味的食物，而他的新应用程序将解决这个问题。许多评论员再次提出了当地生态系统中“白人特权”的幽灵，以及对外籍创始人的明显偏好。 Reecht此后为他的评论道歉。 Kune 引发的社交媒体愤怒促使 56 岁的德国 WordPress 培训师 Stefan Kremer 建立了讽刺网站“Hire A Mzungu”。 Mzungu 是斯瓦希里语中外国人的意思，但通常用普通话来指代白人。正如 Kremer 的网站所说，“如果资金获取的主要限制是可行项目中的 mzungu：这是您的白鼻子出租。”
56 岁的 Kremer 来自靠近丹麦边境的德国北部小镇，已经在内罗毕与当地开发商断断续续地工作了两年。他告诉世界其他地方，虽然该网站确实是为了开玩笑，但它肯定有一个严肃的观点。 “我看到人们在内罗毕以数字游牧者的身份出现，他们为甚至可能不适合当地情况的想法获得资助，”他说。 “每当我在内罗毕与我的同事交谈时，他们都会有解决问题的绝妙想法，有时他们只需要一点点 [少量] 影响力来启动和运行。克雷默的网站显示，外籍人士、创始人和一些投资者的自我意识越来越强，现在围绕这个话题进行了更微妙的对话。 Phares Kariuki 是内罗毕的一位资深科技创始人，正在创办他的第三家初创公司，他表示，除了结构性种族主义之外，非本地创始人获得资助的原因还有细微差别。“过去，我纯粹关注种族主义，但一旦你开始往上走，开始关注当地的问题，你开始接受各种因素的汇合，而不是一个单一的故事，”他告诉世界其他地区。这些因素包括他所描述的肯尼亚薄弱的公司法律体系，以及在主要国际组织（包括在内罗毕的联合国机构）工作后留下来的大量外籍人士。但一个明显的问题是，一旦非洲初创公司度过了天使投资的最早阶段，几乎所有重要的风险投资基金都来自非洲大陆以外。尤其是在内罗毕，这些基金中的大部分都是由外国人管理的。 Kariuki 和其他创始人说，很多时候，投资者并不完全了解当地的情况。甚至承认创始人的本地经验或资历。这反过来又产生了我们在硅谷看到的类似偏见现象，风险投资支持具有相似背景和生活经历的创始人——除了它发生在数千英里之外的东非。内罗毕物流初创公司 Senga Technologies 的创始人 June Odongo 在 2016 年搬回肯尼亚之前在美国度过了她职业生涯的大部分时间。她将其描述为“看起来像我，听起来像我”我认为，这种投资方法会嘲笑非洲主义，而忽略了在这里取得成功所需的当地专业知识。”奥东戈说，这导致“投资者不投资当地企业家，而是经常投资炒作。”
几位受访者表示，解决这个问题的唯一方法是拥有更多植根于当地经济的天使和风险投资。 “最终，你需要加强关心市场的本地投资者阶层，”阿谢比尔说。 “外国创始人不会停止来到非洲大陆。” Future Africa 的创始人 Iyinoluwa Aboyeji 一直专注于建立一个混合本地和外国资本的风险基金来支持本地创始人，他认为肯尼亚的外国投资者需要对他们如何使用资金表现出更多的责任感。 “你来到尼日利亚或肯尼亚，想投资当地企业，但你几乎没有住在这个国家，或者住在这个国家的专属飞地。当这些投资者声称没有[企业家]人才管道，但他们几乎没有参与到生态系统中时，谁要让他们负责？”尼日利亚人 Aboyeji 说，他是 Andela 和 Flutterwave 的共同创始人。 “如果这不是我们的资本，我们就不能争论，即使我们看到它没有得到很好的分配。”事实上，拉各斯现在已经超越了内罗毕早期的科技繁荣，这不仅得益于更大的国民经济和人才库，还得益于 Aboyeji 等本土科技企业家的崛起，他们与当地天使网络一起回馈了下一代创始人投资于他们的想法。这让我们回到了关于自信的 Ngũgĩ 路线。这句话的后半部分可能反映了肯尼亚科技领导者的利害关系，他们希望在创始人抓住机会和当地资本流入风险投资方面重新平衡当地生态系统。 “重视自己，别人也会重视你。来自内部的验证是最好的。”
note_en:
Last month, a  furor broke out on Kenyan social media when a French startup founder, who had only spent a few months in the East African country, seemingly had no trouble raising $1 million in pre-seed funding for his new food delivery app. Meanwhile, local and regional founders say they still have difficulty pulling together capital after years of attempts.
 While talking to a Kenyan tech founder about this last week, I was reminded of a line from Ngũgĩ wa Thiong’o’s memoir,  Dreams in a Time of War: “Belief in yourself is more important than endless worries of what others think of you .” Ngũgĩ was recalling a moment of realization from his childhood in colonial-era Kenya, but the quote feels apt today.
 In the early 2010s, Kenya’s fledgling tech ecosystem was used as a shorthand for a wider “Africa Rising” narrative. It was promptly dubbed “Silicon Savannah” as startups sprouted and tech talent flocked to Nairobi.
 But by 2016, there were mutterings in local circles about how the funding seemed to be disproportionately favoring North American and European founders who were launching companies in the country. Things came to a head in 2017, when a Village Capital  report titled “Breaking the Pattern” appeared to confirm what many local founders and journalists had been saying: In East Africa, 90% of disclosed startup investments in 2015 and 2016 went to companies with one or more European or North American founders. It’s an issue that hasn’t gone away in the last five years, Adedana Ashebir, regional director for Africa and the Middle East for Village Capital, told me.
 Analysis of 2019 data showed that only one of the Kenyan startups that raised more than $1 million that year had a local founder. Four startups had a mix of foreign and local founders, while 11 had expat founders. It’s worth noting that this trend doesn’t apply elsewhere on the continent: In Lagos’ booming tech hub, 55% (12) of the founders identified in the same analysis were Nigerian, while in South Africa, 56% (14) of the founders were locals.
 This comparison with other African markets only serves to deepen the frustration of many of Kenya’s long-term tech watchers. So last month when Robin Reecht, a young French founder on a visitor visa, raised $1 million in pre-seed funding for a Kenyan food delivery app called Kune, a collective eyebrow was raised. But it was a subsequent interview with  TechCrunch that really triggered a loud backlash with #KOT (Kenyans on Twitter) and Kenyan social media users. In it, Reecht is quoted as saying that after just three days in Kenya, he noticed it was “impossible” to get “great food at a cheap price” and that his new app would fix this. Many commentators again raised the specter of  “white privilege” in the local ecosystem and what seems to be a clear preference for expat founders. Reecht has since  apologized for his comments.
  The social media outrage sparked by Kune inspired Stefan Kremer, a 56-year-old German WordPress trainer, to set up the satirical website “ Hire A  Mzungu.” Mzungu is the Kiswahili word for foreigner, but often used in common parlance to refer to a white person. As Kremer’s site has it, “If the main restriction to the access of money is a  mzungu within a viable project: Here’s your white nose for hire.”
 Kremer, 56, who’s from a small northern Germany town near the Danish border, has been working on and off in Nairobi with local developers for two years. He told  Rest of World that while the website was indeed meant to poke fun, there was definitely a serious point to it. “I see people show up in Nairobi as digital nomads and they get funded for ideas that might not even fit the local context,” he said. “Whenever I speak to my guys in Nairobi, they have brilliant ideas that solve a problem and sometimes they just need a small [amount of] leverage to get things up and running.”
 Kremer’s site shows that there’s a growing self-awareness among expats, founders, and some investors, and that there are now more nuanced conversations going on around the topic.
  Phares Kariuki, a veteran tech founder in Nairobi who is on his third startup, said there's nuance in why non-local founders get funded, in addition to structural racism.“In the past, I focused purely on the racism, but once you start going up the layers and start looking at the local problems, you start to accept there are a confluence of factors, not a single story,” he told  Rest of World.
 Those factors include what he describes as a weak corporate legal system in Kenya and a large community of expatriates who stay over after working at major international organizations including the UN agencies in Nairobi.
 But one obvious issue is that once African startups get past the very earliest stage of angel investing, almost all significant venture capital funds originate outside the continent. In Nairobi in particular, most of those funds are managed by foreigners. Kariuki and other founders say that oftentimes, investors don’t fully understand the local context. Or even recognize founders’ local experience or credentials.
 That, in turn, creates a similar bias phenomenon that we see in Silicon Valley, where VCs back founders from a similar background and life experience — except it’s happening thousands of miles away in East Africa. June Odongo, founder of Senga Technologies, a Nairobi-based logistics startup, spent the bulk of her career in the United States before moving back to Kenya in 2016. She describes it as a “looks-like-me-sounds-like-me investing method which, I think, derides Africanism and ignores local expertise required to succeed here.”
  This, Odongo said, leads to “investors who aren’t investing in the local entrepreneurs, but instead are often investing in hype.”
 The only way to address this is to have more angel and venture capital that’s rooted in the local economy, said several interviewees. “Ultimately you need to strengthen a local investor class that cares about the market,” said Ashebir. “Foreign founders are not going to stop coming to the continent.”
 Iyinoluwa Aboyeji, founder of Future Africa, who has focused on building a venture fund with a mix of local and foreign capital to back local founders, argued that foreign investors in Kenya need to show more accountability for how they’re using funds.
 “You’ve come to Nigeria or Kenya, and want to invest in local businesses, but you barely live in the country, or live in an exclusive enclave of the country. Who’s holding these investors accountable when they claim there’s no pipeline of [entrepreneurial] talent, but they’re barely engaged with the ecosystem?” said Aboyeji, a Nigerian who co-founded Andela and Flutterwave. “If it’s not our capital, we can’t argue, even if we see it’s not being well-allocated.”
 Indeed, Lagos has now  eclipsed Nairobi’s early tech boom, benefiting from not just a larger national economy and talent pool, but also the rise of homegrown tech entrepreneurs like Aboyeji who, alongside local angel networks, have given back to the next generation of founders by investing in their ideas.
 Which brings us back to that Ngũgĩ line on self-belief. The second half of that quote perhaps captures what’s at stake for Kenyan tech leaders who want to rebalance the local ecosystem both in terms of founders taking chances and  local capital flowing to venture funding.
 “Value yourself and others will value you. Validation is best that comes from within.”
title: 肯尼亚科技创始人表示，该国存在对北美和欧洲外籍人士的资金偏见；分析：只有一位肯尼亚创始人在 2019 年筹集了 100 万美元以上的资金
title_en: Kenyan tech founders say there is a funding bias toward North American and European expats in the country; analysis: only one Kenyan founder raised $1M+ in 2019
